summary: The Microsoft Excel package provides comprehensive automation capabilities for working with Excel files on Windows. This package uses the Microsoft Office Interop library to interact with Excel applications, enabling you to automate complex spreadsheet operations.
description: :::info Platform Requirement This package is available only on **Windows** platforms and requires Microsoft Excel to be installed.

activate-sheet.name: ActivateSheet
activate-sheet.summary: Activates a sheet by name or index, making it the active worksheet for subsequent operations.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3

tips: Provide either **Sheet Name** or **Sheet Index**, not both. If both are provided, Sheet Index takes precedence.
Sheet indices are 1-based (the first sheet is 1, not 0).
After activating a sheet, all subsequent operations (like Read Cell, Set Range, etc.) will work on the active sheet.
Use [Get Sheets](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-sheets) node to discover available sheet names and indices.

chart-to-image.name: ChartToImage
chart-to-image.summary: Exports a chart from the worksheet to an image file (PNG format).

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: The chart must have a title set in Excel for this node to find it.
If multiple charts have the same title, the first one found is exported.
The image is exported in PNG format with transparent background if applicable.
Chart formatting, colors, and styles are preserved in the exported image.
Use this for generating reports with visual data representations.
The exported image quality is suitable for documents and presentations.

clear-range.name: ClearRange
clear-range.summary: Clears all content and formatting from a range of cells in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
examples.code:
// Range: All-Range
// Clears all cells with data in the active sheet

examples.title: Example 3

tips: This operation clears both **content** and **formatting** (colors, borders, fonts, etc.).
The cells remain in the worksheet structure (they're not deleted).
Use this when you want to reset a range before writing new data.
For clearing an entire sheet by name, use [Clear Sheet](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/clear-sheet).
**All-Range** only clears the "used range" - cells that have or had data.

clear-sheet.name: ClearSheet
clear-sheet.summary: Clears all content from a specific sheet, removing all cell values and formatting.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
examples.code:
// Loop through sheet names
// Sheet Name: message.sheet_name

tips: This operation clears **all content and formatting** from the sheet.
The sheet structure remains (it's not deleted, just emptied).
Use [Delete Sheet](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/delete-sheet) if you want to remove the sheet entirely.
For clearing only a specific range, use [Clear Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/clear-range).
The sheet becomes a completely blank worksheet after this operation.
Any charts, images, or objects on the sheet are also removed.

clone-range.name: CloneRange
clone-range.summary: Copies a range of cells to a destination location, optionally in a different Excel file or sheet. Unlike Copy/Paste Range, this node performs the operation in one step.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: This node combines copy and paste in a single operation.
When **Destination Excel Path** is provided, the destination file is opened, modified, and saved automatically.
Both **values** and **formatting** (colors, borders, fonts) are cloned.
If cloning to a different file, the destination file is saved and closed after the operation.
Sheet indices are 1-based (first sheet is 1, second is 2, etc.).

close-excel.name: CloseExcel
close-excel.summary: Closes an Excel file and releases the application resources. This node properly cleans up COM objects to prevent memory leaks.

examples.title: Example 1
examples.code:
// File Descriptor: message.excel_fd
// The Excel application instance is closed and resources are released

examples.title: Example 2

tips: Always close Excel files when finished to free up system resources and prevent memory leaks.
Unsaved changes will be lost. Use [Save Excel](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/save-excel) before closing if you want to keep changes.
After closing, the file descriptor becomes invalid and cannot be reused.
This node quits the Excel application instance, so all workbooks opened in that instance will be closed.

copy-range.name: CopyRange
copy-range.summary: Copies a range of cells to the clipboard for later pasting. This node should be used together with [Paste Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/paste-range).

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: The copied data stays in the clipboard until pasted or until another copy operation.
This copies both **values** and **formatting** (colors, borders, fonts, etc.).
For copying to a different Excel file or with more control, use [Clone Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/clone-range) instead.
Always follow Copy Range with [Paste Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/paste-range) to complete the operation.

copy-sheet.name: CopySheet
copy-sheet.summary: Creates a copy of a sheet within the same workbook. The copied sheet includes all data, formatting, and formulas.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
examples.code:
// Sheet Name: "Monthly Template"
// Copied Sheet Name: message.month_name  // e.g., "January", "February"

tips: The copied sheet is placed at the end of the workbook.
The copied sheet becomes the active sheet after the operation.
All cell values, formulas, formatting, and structures are copied.
Charts and images are also copied to the new sheet.
The new sheet name must be unique within the workbook.

create-excel.name: CreateExcel
create-excel.summary: Creates a new Excel file at the specified path with a default worksheet.

examples.title: Example 1
examples.code:
// Path: C:\Reports\monthly_report.xlsx
// This creates a blank workbook with one default sheet

examples.title: Example 2
examples.code:
// Path: C:\Automation\macro_enabled.xlsm
// Use .xlsm extension for macro-enabled workbooks

tips: The file is created and immediately closed by this node. Use Open Excel afterwards to work with the file.
If the directory doesn't exist, you'll get an error. Create the directory first using File System nodes if needed.
The created workbook contains one default worksheet named "Sheet1".
Use `.xlsx` for standard Excel files or `.xlsm` for macro-enabled files.

create-sheet.name: CreateSheet
create-sheet.summary: Creates a new sheet in the workbook at the specified position.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3

tips: Sheet names must be unique within a workbook.
Sheet indices are 1-based (position 1 means insert before the first sheet).
If the specified index exceeds the total number of sheets, the new sheet is added at the end.
The new sheet is created with default Excel formatting and is empty.
After creation, the active sheet remains unchanged unless you use [Activate Sheet](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/activate-sheet).

delete-cell.name: DeleteCell
delete-cell.summary: Deletes or clears a specific cell in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: Use **Clear: true** (default) when you want to empty the cell but maintain the worksheet structure.
Use **Clear: false** when you want to remove the cell entirely and shift adjacent cells.
When Clear is `false`, cells to the right shift left to fill the gap.
Clearing removes both the value and any formatting (like colors or borders).
For deleting entire rows or columns, use [Delete Row](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/delete-row) or [Delete Column](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/delete-column).

delete-column.name: DeleteColumn
delete-column.summary: Deletes or clears a column at the specified position in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: When **Clear** is `false`, the column is completely removed and columns to the right shift left.
When **Clear** is `true`, only the content and formatting are removed; the column structure stays.
Use **Clear: false** to remove unwanted columns and compact your data.
Use **Clear: true** to reset a column for reuse while maintaining the structure.
Column indices are 1-based (column 1 = A, column 2 = B, etc.).
Be careful when deleting columns in loops - indices change as columns are deleted.

delete-row.name: DeleteRow
delete-row.summary: Deletes or clears a row at the specified position in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: When **Clear** is `false`, the row is completely removed and rows below shift up.
When **Clear** is `true`, only the content and formatting are removed; the row structure stays.
Use **Clear: false** to remove unwanted rows and compact your data.
Use **Clear: true** to reset a row for reuse while maintaining the structure.
Row indices are 1-based (row 1 is the first row).
Be careful when deleting rows in loops - indices change as rows are deleted.

delete-sheet.name: DeleteSheet
delete-sheet.summary: Deletes a sheet from the workbook by name.

examples.title: Example 1
examples.code:
// File Descriptor: message.excel_fd
// Sheet Name: "Temp Calculations"

examples.title: Example 2
examples.code:
// Loop through old sheet names
// Sheet Name: message.old_sheet_name

tips: Sheet deletion is permanent and cannot be undone.
Excel workbooks must have at least one sheet. You cannot delete the last remaining sheet.
If the deleted sheet was the active sheet, Excel automatically activates another sheet.
Use [Get Sheets](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-sheets) to get a list of all sheets before deletion.

get-column.name: GetColumn
get-column.summary: Retrieves all cell values from a specific column in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
examples.code:
// Column Name: "AA"
// Returns all values from column AA

examples.title: Example 3
Example 4
examples.code:
// Column Name: "D"  // Price column
// Then calculate sum or average from the results

tips: The column is retrieved from row 1 to the last used row.
Only cells with data are included (based on the used range).
Column names are case-insensitive ("A" and "a" are the same).
Cell addresses in the output include dollar signs (e.g., "$A$1", "$A$2").
For getting multiple columns efficiently, use [Get Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-range) instead.

get-formula.name: GetFormula
get-formula.summary: Retrieves formulas from cells in a range and returns them as a dictionary mapping cell addresses to their formulas.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: Cells without formulas return empty strings in the result dictionary.
Formulas are returned in A1 reference style (e.g., `=SUM(A1:A10)`).
Cell addresses in the dictionary keys do not include dollar signs.
Use this to audit which cells contain calculations vs. static values.
For getting cell values (calculated results), use [Get Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-range) instead.

get-hyperlink.name: GetHyperlink
get-hyperlink.summary: Retrieves hyperlink information from a specific cell, including the link address and display text.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: **Address** contains external URLs (http://, https://) or file paths.
**SubAddress** contains internal Excel references (e.g., "Sheet2!A1").
A hyperlink can have both Address and SubAddress (link to a file with a specific location).
**HasHyperlink** is `true` even if the cell has only formatting that looks like a link.
Use this to extract and validate links before processing them.

get-range.name: GetRange
get-range.summary: Reads data from a range of cells and returns it as a table structure with columns and rows.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: The table structure is compatible with [Set Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/set-range) for copying data between sheets.
Use **Headers: true** when your data has column names in the first row for more readable code.
**All-Range** reads only the "used range" (cells that have or had data), not the entire worksheet.
When **Include Hyperlinks** is enabled, each cell value becomes an object with `text` and `hyperlink` properties.
The output can be directly passed to other nodes that accept table format.

get-row.name: GetRow
get-row.summary: Retrieves all cell values from a specific row in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: The row index is 1-based (first row is 1, not 0).
Only cells within the used range are included in the result.
Cell addresses in the output include the dollar signs (e.g., "$A$5", "$B$5").
Use this when you need all values from a specific row for processing.
For getting multiple rows efficiently, use [Get Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-range) instead.

get-sheets.name: GetSheets
get-sheets.summary: Retrieves a list of all sheets in the workbook, optionally including detailed metadata.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: Use **Show Metadata** when you need to know the used range of each sheet.
The `Dimension` property shows the range of cells with data (e.g., "A1:D10").
Sheet indices are 1-based and reflect the order of sheets in the workbook.
This is useful for discovering sheet names dynamically in automated workflows.

insert-column.name: InsertColumn
insert-column.summary: Inserts a new empty column at the specified position in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
examples.code:
// Column Number: 3
// A new blank column is inserted at column C, columns C and beyond shift right

examples.title: Example 3
examples.code:
// Column Number: 5
// Insert column E for calculations

examples.title: Example 4

tips: The column is inserted **before** the specified position. Existing columns shift right.
The new column is completely empty with default formatting.
If the column number exceeds the number of used columns, the column is inserted at the rightmost position of the used range.
Column indices are 1-based (column 1 = A, column 2 = B, etc.).
Formulas in other columns that reference shifted columns are automatically updated.
The width of the new column inherits formatting from adjacent columns.

insert-row.name: InsertRow
insert-row.summary: Inserts a new empty row at the specified position in the active sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
examples.code:
// Row Number: 5
// A new blank row is inserted at row 5, rows 5 and below shift down

examples.title: Example 3
Example 4
examples.code:
// Row Number: message.insert_position
// Useful for inserting rows dynamically based on calculations

tips: The row is inserted **before** the specified position. Existing rows shift down.
The new row is completely empty with default formatting.
If the row number is beyond the last used row, the row is inserted at the end.
Row indices are 1-based (row 1 is the first row).
Formulas in other rows that reference shifted rows are automatically updated.

open-excel.name: OpenExcel
open-excel.summary: Opens an existing Excel file and returns a file descriptor for subsequent operations. This node supports password-protected files and can optionally share the same Excel application instance for files with cross-references (like VLOOKUP to another workbook).

examples.title: Example 1
examples.code:
// The file descriptor will be stored in message.excel_fd
// Path: C:\Data\sales_report.xlsx

examples.title: Example 2
examples.code:
// Path: C:\Data\confidential.xlsx
// Password To Open: Use a credential vault entry

examples.title: Example 3

tips: Always store the file descriptor in a variable (default is `message.excel_fd`) to use in subsequent Excel nodes.
When opening multiple files that reference each other, use the **In File Descriptor** input to share the same Excel application instance.
Set **Visible** to `false` for better performance in production automations.
Use the **Update Links** option when your file depends on external data sources that need to be current.

paste-range.name: PasteRange
paste-range.summary: Pastes the copied range from clipboard to a specified location. This node should be used after [Copy Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/copy-range).

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3

tips: The **From Cell** and **To Cell** define the destination range dimensions.
Both **values** and **formatting** are pasted.
If the destination range is smaller than the copied range, only the portion that fits is pasted.
If the destination range is larger, the copied data is repeated or the extra cells remain unchanged.
Always use [Copy Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/copy-range) before Paste Range.

range-to-image.name: RangeToImage
range-to-image.summary: Exports a range of cells to an image file (PNG format), capturing the exact appearance of the cells including formatting.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: The image captures the **visual appearance** of the range, including:
Cell values and formatting (fonts, colors, alignment)
Borders and gridlines
Background colors and patterns
Merged cells
The range must be valid Excel notation (e.g., "A1:C10").
The exported image is in PNG format with transparent background where applicable.
Use this to create snapshots of formatted reports or data tables.
The image resolution is based on the current screen display settings.
For exporting charts, use [Chart to Image](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/chart-to-image) instead.

read-cell-value.name: ReadCellValue
read-cell-value.summary: Reads the value from a specific cell in the active Excel sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
examples.code:
// Cell: "D5"  // Price column
// The value is stored in message.Value

examples.title: Example 3
Example 4
examples.code:
// Cell: "E10"  // Contains =SUM(E1:E9)
// Returns the calculated result, not the formula

tips: This node returns the **displayed text** of the cell, not the underlying value. For example, if a cell contains the number 1234.56 but is formatted to show "$1,234.56", the node returns "$1,234.56".
Use the active sheet. If you need to read from a different sheet, use [Activate Sheet](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/activate-sheet) first.
For reading multiple cells efficiently, consider using [Get Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-range) instead.
To get formulas instead of values, use [Get Formula](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-formula).

run-macro.name: RunMacro
run-macro.summary: Executes a VBA macro in the Excel workbook. Supports both macros embedded in the workbook and external macro files.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
examples.code:
// If macro is in a specific module:
// Macro Name: "Module1.FormatData"

examples.title: Example 4

tips: The Excel file must be macro-enabled (.xlsm, .xlsb) to contain macros.
Macro names are case-sensitive in some Excel versions.
When using **Macro File Path**, the file is opened, the macro runs, and the file is closed automatically.
If the macro name doesn't include the workbook reference, it's automatically added when using an external file.
Macros can modify the worksheet, so ensure you have backups if testing.
VBA macros must be enabled in Excel's Trust Center for this to work.

save-excel.name: SaveExcel
save-excel.summary: Saves the Excel file to the specified path or saves changes to the current file location.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3

tips: If **Path** is empty, the file is saved to its current location (same as Ctrl+S in Excel).
If **Path** is provided, the file is saved to the new location (same as Save As).
The node automatically detects macro-enabled workbooks (.xlsm) and saves them with the appropriate format.
You can save to a different format by changing the file extension in the path (e.g., .xlsx, .xlsm, .xls).
After saving to a new path, the workbook remains open at the new location.

search-sheet.name: SearchSheet
search-sheet.summary: Searches for a term in a sheet and returns a list of cell addresses where the term was found.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
examples.code:
// Search Term: "PRD-001"
// Returns all cells containing this product code

examples.title: Example 4
Example 5
examples.code:
// Search Term: "error"
// Finds "Error", "ERROR", "error", etc.

tips: The search is **case-insensitive** by default.
The search looks for **partial matches** (e.g., searching "cat" will find "catalog").
Cell addresses are returned without dollar signs (e.g., "A1", not "$A$1").
The search covers only the used range of the sheet.
If no matches are found, an error is thrown (use Continue On Error to handle this).
Search is performed row by row from left to right, top to bottom.

set-active-cell.name: SetActiveCell
set-active-cell.summary: Sets the active cell in the worksheet by address or relative movement from the current position.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
examples.code:
// Target: Down
// Moves from current cell (e.g., A1) to the cell below (A2)

examples.title: Example 3
Example 4
Example 5

tips: Use relative movements (Up, Down, Left, Right) for processing data in loops.
**Row Start** moves to column A of the current row.
**Row End** moves to the last column with data in the current row.
**Next Row** is equivalent to moving down and then to Row Start.
This node only changes the active cell selection; it doesn't modify any data.

set-cell-value.name: SetCellValue
set-cell-value.summary: Sets the value of a specific cell in the active Excel sheet with type formatting support.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4
Example 5

tips: Choose the correct **Format** to ensure Excel treats the data appropriately.
Use `string` format for data like product codes (e.g., "00123") to preserve leading zeros.
Use `number` format for numeric calculations to enable Excel formulas to work with the data.
Use `boolean` format for TRUE/FALSE values in conditional logic.
The cell retains any existing formatting (colors, borders, etc.) but the value is replaced.

set-formula.name: SetFormula
set-formula.summary: Sets a formula in a specific cell in the active Excel sheet.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
examples.code:
// Cell: "E5"
// Formula: "=IF(D5>100,\"High\",\"Low\")"

examples.title: Example 4
Example 5

tips: The formula must start with `=` (equals sign).
Use Excel's standard formula syntax and functions.
Formulas are calculated immediately upon setting.
Use quotes within formulas carefully - escape them in your code if needed.
Cell references are relative unless you use absolute references (e.g., `$A$1`).
Test formulas manually in Excel first to ensure they work correctly.

set-range.name: SetRange
set-range.summary: Writes a table of data to a range of cells starting from a specified cell.

examples.title: Example 1
Example 2
Example 3
Example 4

tips: The **Range** input must be a table object with `columns` (array of strings) and `rows` (array of objects).
When **Headers** is `true`, the node looks for matching column names in row 1 and writes data to those specific columns.
When **Headers** is `false`, data is written sequentially regardless of column names.
The output from [Get Range](/reference/packages/microsoft-excel/get-range) can be directly used as input here.
Large datasets are written efficiently in bulk for better performance.
